reviewText:
A visionnary game, a unique mix of genres, Omikron might be an old game but a lot of recent games could draw inspiration from it. First thing developers should learn from this game is to break the rules, and to create new ones.

This game is a mix of current standard open-world game, shooter and fighting game (as in, Mortal Kombat/Virtua Fighter style), with a real interesting story, in a very well-thought world full of characters with real depth.

Also, David Bowie, the Legend, has an active role in this story. No need to mention the music alone is worth the price. No wonder he accepted to play in this game, it's kind of like his music was: daring, imaginative and rules-breaking.

Only thing I really dislike about this game is the save system. Without this I'd give the game a 11/10, so I'll have to go for a mere 10/10 instead.

reviewText:
***English Version***

(Sorry, nie będzie polskiej wersji, nie mieści się. Chciałem umieścić w komentarzach ale jest limit 1000 znaków)

Omikron: The Nomad Soul is the first game of the Quantic Dream studio. It might as well be considered three games in one. For the major part of the gameplay it remains a TPP adventure game relying on the usual stuff:  talking with NPCs and using items. Occasionally it switches to FPP shooter or hand to hand 1 on 1 brawler kind of similar to early instalments of the Tekken or Virtua Fighter series. It is worth mentioning that all of these are made pretty solid and none of them feels like it was forced into the gameplay without a reason (well, maybe with the exception of swimming, but it occurs 2 or 3 times in the entire game, which is acceptable).

An interesting mechanic incorporated into the gameplay is the switching of the protagonist’s bodies. While it is not possible to reincarnate into any NPC, there certainly is a significant number of possible bodies the ‘Nomad Soul’ can possess. Some of these are plot induced – when your actual shell is killed, you will take over the first person that touches the dead body – yes, dying does not necessarily mean  seeing a game over screen.  Later on you acquire a spell that allows reincarnation whenever you find an interesting host – for instance to gain access to a particular area. Or just for fun.

I find it a bit disappointing that, while all of these NPCs have their statistics (eg. Strength, speed, HP, MP) and some information on their background, likes and dislikes, when you decide to reincarnate, your previous host simply disappears. At no point it is mentioned that what you actually do is stealing the bodies of living people. I believe that this theme is not sufficiently explored or developed during the game.

Surprisingly enough, the graphics of this game are not all that bad (considering the fact it was published in 1999). Of course, models and  textures are simple and the viewing distance is obscured by the mist,  but all of the game’s districts have their own style and color palette that catches the eye. Furthermore, the way the districts look contributes greatly to the  game’s cyberpunk atmosphere. On the other hand, it is noticeable that there are very few models of NPC characters on the street (2 – 3 per district) and vehicles (1 model of a hovercraft-car and 1 bike –  that’s all!). If you decide to play, I strongly suggest overriding the game’s settings in your graphic card’s panel and forcing every possible filtering on – it greatly improves the game’s appearance: especially the character’s faces during the conversations.

Quite obviously, music is where the game excels (David Bowie!) . It needs to be said that not only the tracks featuring David Bowie are awesome (look around the city – you may find a concert going on. ) but the entirety of the soundtrack is an impressive work.

In my mini-reviews I usually do not discuss the game’s story line, and this case should not be an exception. But let me tell you that: at some points of the storyline some of the NPCs will openly say that Omikron is a computer game ( while others will tell you that it is not :D) and it is the integral part of the plot.  It is quite worth playing the game just to discover this particular story gambit.

To conclude: I cannot say whether Omikron is a good game or not. It is certainly an ambitious one.  It is noticeable that lot of work has been put into Quantic Dream’s first child. Still, one can’t help but notice that the later part of the game is significantly weaker, just as if authors ran out of ideas in the end. It doesn’t help that the puzzles in the final chapter of the game are EXTREMELY annoying ( For example – AND THERE WILL BE SPOILERS as I am describing two most annoying riddles in the game – at one point you are required to run around one of the districts, without the use of cabs, looking for four symbols – this task takes more or less half an hour, while solving the riddle when you know the symbols – no more than a minute. Ten minutes later you need to find a gem  - in the chamber where you can get it, there are approximately 20 chests with 20 similar gems – of course the game gives you hints as to which one you should choose but these are quite vague and you are not told in any way whether you picked the right one – and the place where you use the said gem is one hour ahead into gameplay. So yes, if you chose poorly you will be running right back. Or RAGEquit. Anyways, SPOILERS OUT).

If you are still planning to finish this game, it should take around 15 hours. It took me some more time since I decided to lose all the battles and check out the outcomes. My recommendation in this case is: buy this game (discounted!)  to check out where the authors of Indigo Prophecy, Heavy Rain and Beyond: Two Souls started. Play to discover that one major plot twist.  After that, there is not much Omikron has to offer. Be warned: I finished this one solely because I loved it OH SO MUCH back then in primary school.

reviewText:
Before David Cage and his band of merry men decided that an ideal video game should have no gameplay whatsover they managed to rub two braincells together long enough to create what is undoubtedly one of the best lesser known titles the open world/multigenred genre has to offer. Archaic controls and desperately aging graphics aside Omikron takes place in a futuristic cyber punk world drawing heavy inspiration from 80s sci fi movies that really draws the player in both figuratively and literally. You play yourself using your computer to enter the world of Omikron taking over the bodies of a wide cast of characters to solve the mystery of just what exactly is happening to this mysterious world of Omikron.

The gameplay is broken into 3 segments. There is the overworld adventure mode where you take part in an investigation which is where the story mainly unfolds and progresses.
Combat is then split up into Fighting and Shooting. The shooting segments are your standard FPS style controls (though you will what to adjust the controls as the default is the arrow keys and not WASD) and the fighting segments play pretty much exactly like the Tekken games.

All in all Omikron is a fantastic immersive game and while it does suffer from sever early 3D game syndrome such as tank controls wonky interaction mechanics and so on, it is still on of the most innovative and ambitious games I've played to date.

Would highly reccomend
8/10

reviewText:
Omikron is 14 years old, however by no means is that a reason to pass this game up.

While my review may be fueled by nostalgic memories, there are a ton of reasons to still experience this notable cyberpunk RPG.

The Nomad Soul did a lot, and took a lot of chances. In the current development atmosphere where games must be marketed to reach the most absolute mindless of the massess to get the greatest return, this game hails from a time when developers were trying all sorts of things to break the mold. Keep in mind that this was released 2 years prior to the legendary open world RPG Morrowind, yet managed to accomplish having an engaging open world built off fairly interesting and new concept. All of the dialog is voiced, and the world is huge- to a point where it really starts to be a detriment, a mistake Morrowind did not learn from either.

Omikron is not without it's flaws. It is simultaneously an open world RPG, a fighter, a shooter, and maybe something else thrown in there as well.  It does all of these things fairly mediocrely, but combined, it holds up fairly well- particularly for it's age. The story was very dark and very interesting when I had played it in 9th grade. Looking back and revisiting it, it is still very interesting, although is not immune to some cliches that I may not have picked up when I was younger.

Definitely pick the game up on sale just to experience a different time in game development, a developer who took chances with mechanics and genres, had a terrific new IP, and also managed to get robot David Bowie in their game.

reviewText:
There is simply no questioning the artistic integrity of this dated action exploration roleplaying game. Graphically the fidelity has not held up well over the years, but taking in the voracity of its design, here is a piece of art that will leave a lasting impression in the hearts and minds of players for generations. There's no question that the purity of vision afforded by the influence of the incomprable David Bowie is a driving force in the emotional tangibility of this world.

Bowie provides several songs which serve as set pieces for the digital stage, and also cameos as a guiding character with the peculiarity and vision we expect from the creative visionary. Always a leader in many frontiers, the digital in particular, one might easily forgive the less than fluid manner in which different game styles are meshed in ways later perfected, but rarely with such passion.

A screenshot has the presense of a painted work of art, a feat rare when this game was released. It is unflinchingly challenging, with themes sexual and moral that will bring the jaded player pause. What are you doing and why? For whom? A question this game seeks to explore, where only you can provide the answer.

A rare game that suits its most notable collaborator. The daring and adventurous would be remiss in passing this game by. Do yourself a favor and study this piece, as it is of the time and timeless in its presentation.

reviewText:
A crazy ride right into David Cage's mind, Omikron: The Nomad Soul is an open world adventure with fighting and shooting sequences. It's a very ambitious game with its bold use of a very early version of motion capture technology, a big open world fleshed out with content (big for 1999, understandably nothing special compared to today's open world games), and last but not least an original soundtrack by David Bowie, who also graces us with his voice acting talent.

After being asked to send your soul into a police officer's body in a parallel universe, you replace him in the futuristic city of Omikron, and try to figure out what's going on in this distant, alien world. Then it doesn't take long to figure out that nothing in Omikron is what it seems.

Unfortunately Quantic Dream bit off more than they could chew. The shooting minigame is tedious, the driving minigame adds nothing to the game, and the pacing is completely ruined in the last few hours. Apparently they ran out of time and budget near the end of development, and wrapped it up quickly.

Still, go ahead and give it a try if you don't mind imperfect, ambitious games which motivate the player to explore the world and discover little stuff.

reviewText:
My feelings towards Omikron are very mixed. It is certainly one of the most unique games I've played... but it's a bit too unique for my liking. What I mean is, the game has a lot of variety- but not a lot of variety in it's actual gameplay. There are sections where you walk around and talk to people, sections where you swim, sections where you shoot enemies, and sections where you fight Mortal Kombat style. But there isn't much variation to this at all, and each gameplay has some hick in it; something that makes it really clunky to play around with.

The graphics are fine in Omikron. I have no problem with them. But my problem is the animation. Faces make strange expressions and people over-emote by gesturing wildly. It's almost comical to watch at times. As far as stories go, Omikron's is the most involving I've played. It goes to great lengths to make sure that you know that you are NOT playing a game, but interacting with a very real world with very real consequences... but that had no effect on me, as I would often correct my mistakes by booting my old save up and trying again. And the design of the world and flow of the story is way too vague for me. A lot of the game almost requires you to look up a game guide, as the answers to a lot of the puzzles are borderline impossible. And sometimes just trying to find out what EXACTLY you have to do next in order to progress the story can be a massive pain, as you don't telepathically know what the game is requiring you to do.

As far as the world and lore of Omikron goes, it's fine, but it has the same problem that Dragon Age: Origins only suffered slightly from- reading. A good lore can be told with subtlties between characters and showing in the dispaly of the world itself. I'd rather see mages practice magic than go to a library and study and make my own damn Beshe'm. (And I PERSONALLY want to know the people who knew how to make a flipping Besehe'm with no guide because none of the stuff I did to make it made any sense at all!)

I personally don't like Omikron for it's faults. If it wanted it's consequences to matter, well I'd applaud Quantic Dream for doing a much better job of getting that across in Heavy Rain years later. But as Quantic's first production, Omikron suffers from some massive problems as a game, but it still has charm to it. There is freedom in the open world of Omikron, characters can be fun to interact with, and there is a certain draw I had to the game before I got really tired of playing it really fast- since the missions for The Awakened can get repetitive very quickly.

If you want a gaming experience like none you've played before, Omikron is certainly one to fill that desire. But as far as great games go, I'm pretty sure Omikron won't stand the test of time to become a legend.

reviewText:
If you are here to see Bowie, you must know a few things. You must be ready to take a lot of abuse if you plan to play this game. Seriously, this is not an easy game to like.

Controls are awful. First of all Nomad Soul doesn’t support analog joysticks so xbox360 controller is out of the question. Keybindings affect menus so after changing them to WASD you have to use menus with WASD and there is no mouse support. Most of the time you move around in a city, talking to people and searching for places. In these section you can’t strafe or use mouse look. Usable objects are not highlighted and sometimes hidden in places that you can't see them. You find them by accident. Textures are so muddy that it’s really easy to miss doors, since everything looks so flat. You can only save at set save points which are really far apart. Fighting is not well made and while the first person shooter element works, it's really really clunky.

On my machine the game runs perfectly well exept when there is a lot of non-polygonal (sprite) objects on screen. For example the inventory screen is made mostly of sprites and runs at horrific frame rate that makes it really difficult to use.

I’m not trying to bring the game down. Just saying that a 1990’s pc player mindset is needed to enjoy. Just to see the cutscenes i'll recommend a let's play. If I can keep going, I’ll post a proper review later.

reviewText:
I played this when it first released and almost finished it back then. I got it on Steam because of David Bowie's death and Square Enix giving it for free, which is a very nice move from their part.

Unfortunately, I don't recommend this game.

As usually, David Cage's hubris promises a lot and delivers nothing.
The writing is clunky, the overall appearance is ugly, the world feels empty and the controls are awful : they change all the time, from relative to the camera to absolute, from keyboard and mouse to controller. Don't get fooled by those who say that WASD wasn't a standard at that time. It was. The only other games from that period that used tank controls were Grim Fandango and FFVII (PC port) and at least, they sticked to them. Omikron wants to be everything and achieves nothing.

If you're here because of David Bowie, you're better off watching excerpts on Youtube. And frankly, these are not very interesting songs.
If you want to play a game from the same year, from other hubris driven french speaking developers, play Outcast and just compare. Being a game from 1999 is not an excuse.

reviewText:
A game from 1999 that isn't up to standard any more.

From the sexist fart with the messiah complex who gave you Heavy Rain and Fahrenheit / Indigo Prophecy, comes the very first Quantic Dream game, which doesn't play quite like the others, but kinda does. It's basically (very basically) an open-world RPG, but the progression is linear and there's not much point in exploring. The main part of the game is going from point A to point B. If any combat is involved, it's either a first-person shoot-em-up or a beat-em-up, both again very basic.

The game is best known for having David Bowie, which is only really of benefit to Bowie fans. He's in that elite of Phil Collins, Rod Stewart et al where if you don't like all their stuff then their non-single songs are gonna bore the pants off you (personally I'm a Phil Collins guy).

It might've been worth playing in 1999, but now, unless you're a Bowie megafan, there's probably another RPG in your backlog or being given away 'free' on Xbox or PS Plus that you'd enjoy far more.

reviewText: I took a gamble on this game in spite of the mediocre reviews because i love sci-fi adventures. Unfortunately, it seems i don't have the patience any more for this era of game. The default controls are woeful, though you can WASD-ify them to make it slightly less awkward (no mouselook, though). I was still semi-interested in the world right up until the first battle. The FPS mode is very slippery and difficult to enjoy, but the fighting game mode is the real fun-killer, and this is coming from someone who played the hell out of the first three Mortal Kombat games as a kid. Perhaps it would be easier with a gamepad, but it's almost impossible to get your guy to do what you want with a mouse and keyboard. Given the savegames are all checkpoint-style and you have to go back 5+ minutes to replay the fight it's just not worth my time. The story seems like it could have been okay, but with controls like these it simply doesn't stand up to the countless modern games you could be spending your time and money on.
